The Conversion Formulas

There are two formulas you need:

Fahrenheit to Celsius: Â°C = (Â°F - 32) Ã— 5/9

Celsius to Fahrenheit: Â°F = (Â°C Ã— 9/5) + 32

Example â€” 72Â°F to Celsius:

Example â€” 30Â°C to Fahrenheit:

Mental Math Tricks

You donâ€™t need exact precision for most situations. These shortcuts get you close enough:

Quick Fahrenheit to Celsius: Subtract 30, then divide by 2.

  • 80Â°F â†’ (80 - 30) Ã· 2 = 25Â°C (actual: 26.7Â°C â€” close enough!)
  • 50Â°F â†’ (50 - 30) Ã· 2 = 10Â°C (actual: 10Â°C â€” perfect!)

Quick Celsius to Fahrenheit: Double it, then add 30.

  • 20Â°C â†’ (20 Ã— 2) + 30 = 70Â°F (actual: 68Â°F â€” close!)
  • 35Â°C â†’ (35 Ã— 2) + 30 = 100Â°F (actual: 95Â°F â€” reasonable estimate)

These shortcuts are accurate within a few degrees â€” more than good enough for deciding what to wear.

â“ Frequently Asked Questions

What is the formula to convert Fahrenheit to Celsius? â–¼

Â°C = (Â°F - 32) Ã— 5/9. Subtract 32 from the Fahrenheit temperature, then multiply by 5/9.

What is the formula to convert Celsius to Fahrenheit? â–¼

Â°F = (Â°C Ã— 9/5) + 32. Multiply the Celsius temperature by 9/5 (or 1.8), then add 32.

What temperature is the same in both Fahrenheit and Celsius? â–¼

-40 degrees is the same in both scales. -40Â°F = -40Â°C. It's the only point where the two scales intersect.

Why does the US use Fahrenheit? â–¼

The US adopted Fahrenheit in the colonial era from Britain. While most countries switched to Celsius as part of the metric system, the US never made the full transition. Fahrenheit remains standard for weather and cooking in the US.
